Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Illapel Earthquake and Tsunami - Environmental Impacts on the North Central Chile Coast
Award.AbstractNarration:
On September 16, 2015 a Mw8.3 earthquake and accompanying tsunami struck the coast of north-central Chile. This rapid response project documents the geomorphic impacts of the event by collecting perishable physical data, which is being rapidly lost due to post-earthquake reconstruction and post-depositional change. The project enables comparison of the 2015 Illapel event with paleoearthquakes and tsunamis discovered during previous NSF-funded fieldwork in north-central Chile. Rapidly dispatched survey teams will collect data from the Illapel earthquake and tsunami from existing and new study sites. The field, laboratory, and modeling research will: (1) assess co-seismic and post-seismic land-level change; (2) investigate sedimentary deposits and geomorphic impacts of the tsunami; and (3) compare model simulations of the 2015 tsunami to run-up measurements and surveying data.

Despite the frequency of earthquakes and tsunamis in north-central Chile, very few studies have been directed at the geologic impacts of historical and prehistoric events. Geologic records of earthquakes and tsunamis can expand the range of events available for study, thereby improving the understanding of subduction zone hazards. The 2015 Illapel earthquake and tsunami provide an invaluable opportunity to examine the nature of co-seismic land-level change and tsunami evidence in this region. The project advances desired societal outcomes through full participation of women in STEM through support of an early career female PI and her female collaborators, improved well-being of individuals in society through a better understanding of tsunami hazards in Chile, development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce through post-doctoral researcher and student training and increased partnerships between academia and government researchers as well as a strong international collaboration. The Earth Sciences Division Deep Earth Processes Section and the Office of International Science and Engineering support the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On September 16, 2015 a magnitude 8.3 earthquake and accompanying tsunami struck the coast of north-central Chile. The effects of the tsunami—one of the three largest events to affect north-central Chile in the last ~300 years—were felt along ~500 kilometers of coastline. The tsunami registered as high as 4.5 meters on regional tide gauges, however we found physical evidence of tsunami run-up heights exceeding 10 meters at exposed locations. Historical accounts indicate that similar large earthquakes (magnitude >8.0) and tsunamis (>5 m) affected the north-central Chile coast in AD 1880 and AD 1943, yet the sedimentary evidence and coastal impacts of the three largest regional events remains undocumented.


The 2015 north-central Chile tsunami provided a unique opportunity to document the evidence of tsunami inundation in a semi-arid environment, improving our ability to identify such evidence in the geologic record. Geologic records of earthquakes and tsunamis improve our understanding of subduction zone hazards by expanding the range of events available for study beyond the historical and instrumental period, thereby capturing great earthquakes and tsunamis that recur centuries to millennia apart.


We explored the effects of the 2015 tsunami on coastal marshes in north-central Chile in January 2016. We discovered sand layers from the 2015 tsunami in two marshes south of the resort community of La Serena.  The physical characteristics (grain size, organic content) of the sand layers were consistent with the size of tsunami waves expected from the magnitude 8.3 earthquake. We also discovered a buried sand layer with very similar physical characteristics to the 2015 tsunami deposit. Our modeling results suggest that the older sand layer was most likely deposited by a prior tsunami generated by a 2015-style earthquake. Dating of the older sand layer is ongoing, but preliminary results suggest it was deposited by a tsunami produced by the AD 1880 earthquake. The discovery of the older sand layer was the first physical evidence of pre-20th century tsunami inundation documented along the north-central Chile coast. 


Our work characterizing the sedimentary evidence of the 2015 tsunami led to the discovery of a previously undocumented event, extending the tsunami history of the region and providing a more complete picture of subduction zone hazards in north-central Chile. The insights gained in this project can be applied to comparable settings in semi-arid environments around the world, and will help determine how to best prepare for future earthquakes and tsunamis.


Our international, interdisciplinary team from Rutgers University, Central Washington University, and the Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Chile involved exchanges of expertise with immediate and lasting impacts on our research and training. Undergraduate and graduate students participated in the planning and implementation of fieldwork, were trained in laboratory, statistical, and modeling techniques, and used samples collected during this project and models of the tsunami to generate and test relevant research questions. In addition, the project provided an opportunity for the PI (postdoctoral researcher) to gain valuable experience leading a research team and mentoring both undergraduate and graduate students. Outreach efforts by the research team at multiple STEM events targeted students who are underrepresented in science careers.
